[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: from_file()] [Panic-based DoS] Does the unwrap() at line 67 for bcs::from_bytes() allow an attacker to panic validator nodes by providing malformed BCS data, causing deterministic crashes across all validators that load the corrupted error map? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: from_file()] [Type Confusion] Can an attacker craft BCS data that deserializes to an ErrorMapping struct with type-confused fields, causing undefined behavior when error codes are later accessed, potentially leading to incorrect error reporting that masks critical security issues? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: from_file()] [Integer Overflow in BCS] Does the BCS deserialization at line 67 properly validate that BTreeMap sizes fit in memory, or can an attacker provide a file claiming to have u64::MAX entries, causing integer overflow in size calculations and heap corruption? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: to_file()] [Panic-based DoS] Does the unwrap() at line 72 for File::create() allow an attacker to panic validator nodes if the filesystem is read-only or disk is full, causing node crashes during error map persistence? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: to_file()] [Panic-based DoS] Does the unwrap() at line 73 for file.write_all() allow an attacker to panic validator nodes if disk space runs out mid-write, potentially corrupting the error map file and causing future load failures? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: to_file()] [Panic-based DoS] Does the unwrap() at line 71 for bcs::to_bytes() allow an attacker to panic validator nodes if serialization fails due to excessively large error maps, causing validator crashes during error map updates? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: to_file()] [Partial Write Corruption] If write_all() at line 73 fails mid-write but the unwrap() panics before cleanup, can this leave a partially-written corrupted error map file that causes all future from_file() calls to fail, permanently breaking error reporting? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: to_file()] [Atomic Write Violation] Does to_file() perform atomic file writes (write-then-rename pattern), or can a crash mid-write leave a corrupted error map that breaks all subsequent error lookups, potentially masking critical consensus failures? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: add_error_category()] [Error Masking] If an attacker can cause add_error_category() to fail with a duplicate error at line 37-40, does this bail() prevent loading a critical security-related error category, potentially masking consensus failures as generic errors? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: add_error_category()] [Integer Collision] Can an attacker deliberately register error categories with carefully chosen category_id values that collide with critical system error codes (e.g., 0, 1, u64::MAX), causing system errors to be misreported and potentially masking consensus or fund transfer failures? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: add_module_error()] [Race Condition] If multiple threads call add_module_error() concurrently for the same module and abort_code, can the check at line 55 pass for both threads before either inserts, allowing duplicate error descriptions and breaking deterministic error reporting across validators? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: add_module_error()] [Module Name Collision] Can an attacker register error codes for a module name that looks identical to a system module (using Unicode lookalikes, homoglyphs, or zero-width characters), causing error lookups to return attacker-controlled descriptions that mask real security issues? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/move-core/types/src/errmap.rs] [Function: add_module_error()] [Error Shadowing] If an attacker can register error descriptions before legitimate system modules are initialized, can they shadow critical error codes with misleading descriptions, causing validators to misdiagnose consensus failures as benign errors?
